name: Nigerian Jollof
description: A delicious and iconic Nigerian dish made with rice cooked in a flavorful tomato sauce.
steps: Prepare the sauce by frying onions and tomatoes
Add the rice to the sauce and cook until done
notes: Serve with fried plantains or steamed vegetables. For a vegetarian version, omit the meat.

nutrition.tips: For extra flavor, use freshly ground crayfish and add a bay leaf while cooking.

name: Egusi Soup
description: A popular Nigerian soup made with melon seeds, packed with flavor and nutrition.
steps: Add palm oil and egusi, then simmer with vegetables until thickened
notes: Serve with pounded yam, eba, or fufu. Add more spices for a kick.

nutrition.tips: For a thicker soup, let the egusi simmer longer.

name: Pounded Yam and Efo Riro
description: A classic Nigerian dish served with richly spiced vegetable stew.
steps: Boil the yam and pound until smooth
Prepare the efo riro by frying palm oil, adding vegetables, and cooking the meat
Serve together with the pounded yam
notes: Perfect for lunch or dinner. Add shrimp for extra flavor.

nutrition.tips: Use a wooden mortar and pestle for the best pounded yam texture.

name: Suya
description: A spicy grilled meat skewer popular in Nigeria, known for its rich and smoky flavor.
steps: Season with suya spice and let it marinate
Serve with sliced onions and vegetables
notes: Best enjoyed as street food or at a barbecue. Serve with a cold drink.

nutrition.tips: For a smokier flavor, use a charcoal grill.

name: Moi Moi
description: A steamed bean pudding made from blended peeled beans, enjoyed across Nigeria.
steps: Blend beans with peppers and onions
Mix in palm oil, fish, and seasoning
Steam in a mold until set
notes: Serve as a side dish or breakfast. Pair with rice or bread.

nutrition.tips: Use banana leaves instead of foil for a more traditional flavor.
